speaker: Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
vclaim: John Vaus says he "rejection of the scheduled vote" for trying to kill the health care protection provided by the Obamaker program.
date: stated on October 30, 2018 in a campaign ad:
title: Who's to blame for the murder of Obamacker? Democrats refer to John Faus in New York.
text: In 2017, when the Republicans considered measures to abolish and replace the Obama Care Program, the budget committee of the House of Representatives took an important initial vote. From 19 to 17 it decided to promote the American Health Care Act. This means, as the Democratic Party says, that the Republic of Jon Vu of New York left the scheduled vote to deny protection to pre-existing conditions. This claim is made in a new announcement to the Congressional Campaign Committee on Air in the closing days of the race in New York, Congress Department 19 South Albany, where Burkina Faso faces a challenge from Antonio Delgado. Burkina Faso, according to the Department of Social Welfare, could have stopped the entire bill, which critics say could have been extremely harmful to persons in need of the protection provided for by the Affordable Care Act. It failed only later because the Senate lacked support for a copy of it. Was Burkina Faso the decision? Let's look at math. On March 16, 2017, the budget committee voted 19-17. This means that it succeeded by two votes. But if one of the legislators who voted yes hadn't voted instead, Count 18-18 would have been even. "It fails if it is a tie," said DCC spokesman Ivan Lukaski. And that could have stopped everything he followed, as he said. Couldn't any of the others have done the same? How can you say that one of the members was a decisive vote? The Coordinating Committee allows that any member may have made a difference, but this does not mean that Burkina Faso was not the key. Three other Republicans voted against the bill because they thought that the bill did not do enough to kill the health programme. Whatever the reasons, Burkina Faso could have joined it. "He could have made the decision to kill him," said Lucassie. In fact, The Herald Riccard, a newspaper covering the Hudson Valley, had a first page with the picture of Burkina Faso and its main title, "The planned vote," with a story that Congressman maintained "the controversial health-care bill alive." The first page appears in the DCCC Declaration. The problems with the bill were the Committee ' s vote to pass the bill along, a necessary step to put the bill on the floor of the House of Representatives. But the Republican leaders, including President Paul Ryan, have admitted that it will take changes to win the approval of the House of Representatives. When the Budget Committee voted, the bill contained provisions calling for the reduction of medical aid payments to the states. It provides for the abolition of penalties for persons who refuse to purchase health insurance. She called for a change in the system of subsidies for those who bought coverage. It could have reduced the rule that insurance companies could pay their older customers three times the premiums they paid the youngest. The Budget Office of Congress estimated that the bill, as it existed at that stage, would have resulted in 14 million more people not being insured in 2018, up to 21 million in 2020 and 24 million in 2026. The Democrats and health policy groups warned that if states received less money for Medicaid, they would retreat from their programs, leaving some people with fewer medical services or more obstacles to registration. Older clients with private insurance would face price increases, and subsidies to help pay would not be sufficient. On January 13, 2021, the distinguished fact-checkers announced in a story in which General David H. Berger, commander of the US Navy, rejected Nancy Belusi's request for open security, and told her that we were "not working for you." On January 17, 2021, Republicans in favour of the bill indicated that it included funds to help states stabilize their insurance markets. The Central Bureau of States has said that such grants may be used "to determine the costs of very high-claim insurance companies." At this stage, would the draft law have eliminated the protections already in place, as the Administrative Committee on Coordination claims? The answer is indirectly that it could have weakened protection - but the question is academic because the Council made changes to the bill before its adoption in May 2017. One amendment contained an amendment allowing States to seek exemptions from other rules of anti-corruption law, including an amendment that health policy groups said could have eroded the requirements for medical services for patients in greatest need. This may lead to a new round of debate on the final House of Representatives Bill, but we have covered it over and over again and the point here is different: the Administrative Coordination Committee says that Burkina Faso could have stopped everything by the vote of its Committee. Our judgment says that John Fawzi refuses to vote to deny protection to the conditions that existed before. Before we rule, it is important to note that states have their own insurance rules before ACA. New York has already banned higher premiums on the basis of health status. This matter was considered more fully by Politi Fukte when considering a related allegation concerning Burkina Faso. We are interested here to know whether Burkina Faso is the decisive vote - and whether, as the Declaration suggests, it can stop everything. There is no need to go a long way in deciding, because the same kind of allegation was used by Republicans against Democrats in previous elections, when Republicans blew up Democrats because they passed the anti-corruption law in the first place. They noted the need for a procedural proposal for the adoption of the draft law by one vote. Here were some of those allegations: Bill Nelson "the decisive vote" on the Health Care Act (2012), Warner "the equivalent vote" on Obamacare (2013), Mark Odall "exceeded Obama's care with his vote" (2014), Ross Fengold voted Obama Health Care (2015), there are more, but you get the idea. Burkina Faso was one of the 19 members of the Budget Committee of the Chamber of Deputies and voted in favour of the early version of the bill to repeal and replace the Council last year. If he had voted no, things would have changed. But the same can be said of 18 others. To point out that Vaso is the only bad guy or hero who overplays his role. Just like we've done over and over again in ACA's claim, we're assessing this claim mostly wrong.
